title: Call of Abram
shortSummary: Genesis 12 marks a pivotal moment in biblical history with God's call to Abram to leave his homeland and journey to an unknown land. This chapter introduces the Abrahamic covenant, promising Abram blessings, a great nation, and a universal blessing through his seed. It also recounts Abram's faith in obeying God and the challenges he faces, including a famine and his sojourn in Egypt.
timeline: c. 2000 BC - The Call of Abram and Early Patriarchal Period

keyCharacters.name: Abram
keyCharacters.description: The central figure called by God to leave his country and become the father of a great nation; demonstrates faith and obedience in this chapter.

keyCharacters.name: Sarai
keyCharacters.description: Abram's wife, noted for her beauty; involved in the deception in Egypt to protect Abram.

keyCharacters.name: Lot
keyCharacters.description: Abram's nephew who accompanies him on the journey from Haran to Canaan.

keyCharacters.name: Pharaoh
keyCharacters.description: The Egyptian ruler who takes Sarai into his house, unknowingly causing God's judgment upon his household.

definitions.definition: Relatives or family members; in this context, Abram is commanded to leave his extended family.
A structure built for worship and sacrifice to God, symbolizing devotion and covenant relationship.
A temporary stay in a place; Abram sojourns in Egypt due to famine.
Divine favor and protection; God promises to bless Abram and those who bless him.

outline.heading: God’s Call and Promise to Abram
outline.description: God commands Abram to leave his homeland and promises to make him a great nation, bless him, and make him a blessing to all families of the earth, establishing the foundation of the Abrahamic covenant.

outline.heading: Abram’s Obedient Departure
outline.description: Abram obeys God’s command, taking Sarai, Lot, and their possessions, demonstrating faith and trust in God’s guidance.

outline.heading: Journey Through Canaan and Worship
outline.description: Abram travels through Canaan, builds altars to the LORD, and receives God’s promise of land to his descendants, showing his worship and reliance on God.

outline.heading: Famine and Sojourn in Egypt
outline.description: A severe famine forces Abram to go to Egypt where he deceives Pharaoh by claiming Sarai is his sister, resulting in divine intervention and Abram’s safe departure.

application: Trust God’s promises even when the future is uncertain, as Abram did by leaving his familiar surroundings.
Obedience to God requires faith and action, demonstrated by Abram’s immediate departure upon God’s command.
In times of hardship, seek God’s protection and guidance rather than relying solely on human schemes.
Remember that God’s blessings are not only for personal benefit but also to be a blessing to others.

keyVerses.text: And I will make of thee a great nation, and I will bless thee, and make thy name great; and thou shalt be a blessing:
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights God’s covenant promise to Abram, emphasizing blessing, nationhood, and a purpose to bless others.

keyVerses.text: And I will bless them that bless thee, and curse him that curseth thee: and in thee shall all families of the earth be blessed.
keyVerses.significance: It reveals God’s protective promise over Abram and the universal scope of blessing through him.

keyVerses.text: So Abram departed, as the LORD had spoken unto him; and Lot went with him: and Abram was seventy and five years old when he departed out of Haran.
keyVerses.significance: This verse underscores Abram’s faithful obedience despite his age and uncertain future.

keyVerses.text: And the LORD plagued Pharaoh and his house with great plagues because of Sarai Abram's wife.
keyVerses.significance: It demonstrates God’s intervention to protect His covenant plan and Abram’s family.
